title: JPMorgan elevates potential successors to Jamie Dimon
text:
JPMorgan Chase has elevated two potential successors to chief executive Jamie Dimon in a reshuffle of its top ranks in which co-chief operating officer Gordon Smith will step down from his roles at the end of the year.

Smith, 62, is currently co-president and co-chief operating officer alongside investment banking chief Daniel Pinto, and also heads JPMorgan's consumer and community banking unit, the bank's largest division by revenue.

JPMorgan veterans Marianne Lake, 51, and Jennifer Piepszak, 51, will become co-heads of CCB, the bank said on Tuesday. Both are considered potential replacements for Dimon when he eventually steps down.

Since 2019, Lake has been head of JPMorgan's consumer lending unit. She was previously group chief financial officer from 2013 to 2019. Piepszak succeeded Lake as CFO.

Dimon, who is 65 and underwent emergency heart surgery last year, has led the bank since 2006. The JPMorgan board has said it would like Dimon to stay a “significant number of additional years”, the bank said.

“We are fortunate to have two such superb executives in Marianne and Jenn — they both are examples of our extremely talented and deep management bench,” Dimon said in a statement.

At the helm of CCB, the two women will oversee a business that generated $51.3bn in revenue last year, about 42 per cent of JPMorgan's total turnover, and has more than 120,000 employees.

“It looks like a two-woman race for the CEO job of JPMorgan,” Wells Fargo analyst Mike Mayo told the Financial Times.

“The ultimate make-up at the top of JPM will also incrementally better represent the population of the US given additional proportionate diversity, which is an objective of JPM,” Mayo and colleagues wrote in a note to clients.

“Marianne and Jenn are both terrific business people,” Smith said in an interview. “They have really great business acumen, they're really thoughtful, they have a good view out in the future strategically.”

Jeremy Barnum, 48, currently head of global research for JPMorgan's corporate and investment bank, will succeed Piepszak as finance chief.

Once Smith leaves, Pinto, 58, will become sole president and chief operating officer. Smith will remain with JPMorgan as a senior adviser to Dimon and other executives.

“I have been thinking about my succession over the last couple of years. My wife and I became grandparents over Christmas and we discussed this then,” said Smith.

“I helped the bank pilot through Covid and Jamie's health scare [in 2020], so it felt 2022 would be the right time to take a step back.”
